key_insight: State-of-the-art vision-language models can predict human binary perceptual preferences for compressed images and be used as effective perceptual judges or losses to align image compression with human judgment.
problem_solved: Bridges the gap between cheap pixel-wise objectives (e.g., MSE) and costly human psycho-visual evaluations by providing a scalable model-based proxy for human perceptual preference in image compression.
method: Use pretrained VLMs to score/compare original vs. compressed images (zero-shot or lightly calibrated) as proxy human preference judgments.
Convert VLM preference outputs into a training signal or differentiable perceptual loss to optimize compression models.
Validate alignment by comparing VLM judgments, traditional metrics (MSE/SSIM), and human studies across benchmarks.
impact: Enables development of compression systems that better match human perception without expensive large-scale psychophysical data collection; practitioners can plug VLM-based judges into training and evaluation pipelines for more human-aligned outputs.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: image -> compressor -> compressed image -> VLM judge -> loss -> compressor update

paper_title: VLIC: Vision-Language Models As Perceptual Judges for Human-Aligned Image Compression
paper_authors: Kyle Sargent, Ruiqi Gao, Philipp Henzler, Charles Herrmann, Aleksander Holynski
